subsection_content:
Acute pyelonephritis is diagnosed based on clinical examination and paraclinical tests.
1. Clinical:
To diagnose acute pyelonephritis, doctors often rely on sudden symptoms, with the following manifestations:
Symptoms of infection: High fever, chills, headache, fatigue, dry lips, dirty tongue...; Symptoms of acute bladder: painful urination, urinary urgency, difficulty urinating, hematuria, cloudy urine, pus in urine; Symptoms of pain: Pain in the back and ribs, tender to the touch, usually on one side, rarely on both sides. Renal colic may occur.
2. Paraclinical diagnosis:
Blood count test: Acute pyelonephritis is an infection, so the patient will be prescribed a blood count test to check for a clearly increased white blood cell index. Especially the phenomenon of polymorphonuclear leukocytosis; Acute blood culture: Determine which group of bacteria the urinary tract infection is caused by. Usually 80% of the causes of disease are determined to be due to infection with Gram (-) E. Coli. bacteria; Ultrasound: Acute pyelonephritis will be detected easily if the patient has an ultrasound to look for signs of dilated renal pelvis, dilated ureters, images of kidney stones - urinary tract, tumor compression...; Cystography: Patients are prescribed X-rays if bladder-kidney reflux is suspected.
In addition, to determine pyelonephritis, the doctor may prescribe additional tests such as: Proteinuria, bacteriuria culture to confirm the diagnosis and have an antibiotic profile for treatment.
People with kidney stones are at risk of acute pyelonephritis
